results.title: You Flushed the Toilet. They Made Some Bricks.
results.abstract: Converting biosolids into building materials could keep a lot of leftovers of the waste process out of landfills, and provide other environmental benefits, too.

multimedia.caption: Abbas Mohajerani holds a brick made with biosolid waste, or treated wastewater sludge.
Abbas Mohajerani holds a brick made with biosolid waste, or treated wastewater sludge.

results.title: How NASA’s Curiosity Rover Weighed a Mountain on Mars
results.abstract: With a bit of technical improvisation, scientists worked out that the bedrock of Mount Sharp appeared to be less dense than had been expected.

multimedia.caption: A self-portrait taken by NASA's Curiosity rover in June 2018 in the Gale Crater, at the center of which stands Mount Sharp, a 3.4-mile-high mound.

results.title: We Tried 5 Cold-Weather Experiments. Instant Slushies, Frozen Bubbles and More.
results.abstract: With schools closed and temperatures well below zero, one family learned some hard lessons about the scientific process.

multimedia.caption: Near Chicago, where the temperature reached a high of minus 10 degrees on Wednesday, reporter Katie Thomas pursued a few scientific inquiries. The bubbles did indeed freeze, but most were whipped away before they could be properly scrutinized.
multimedia.copyright: Danielle Scruggs for The New York Times

results.title: High Ceilings and a Lovely View: Denisova Cave Was Home to a Lost Branch of Humanity
results.abstract: The mysterious Denisovans may have occupied a cave in what is now Siberia for more than 250,000 years.

multimedia.caption: Researchers in the Denisova Cave in Siberia, including archaeologist Katerina Douka, second left. They have found that the cave was continuously occupied for over 300,000 years.
Researchers in the Denisova Cave in Siberia, including archaeologist Katerina Douka, second left. They have found that the cave was continuously occupied for over 300,000 years.

results.abstract: Researchers identified hundreds of gene variations that may be connected to when people go to bed.

results.title: This Is Your Brain Off Facebook
results.abstract: Planning on quitting the social platform? A major new study offers a glimpse of what unplugging might do for your life. (Spoiler: It’s not so bad.)

multimedia.caption: Subjects in a Stanford study had to be paid $100 on average to quit Facebook for a month. At the end, they were less politically polarized than people in a comparison group.
Subjects in a Stanford study had to be paid $100 on average to quit Facebook for a month. At the end, they were less politically polarized than people in a comparison group.

results.title: Germs in Your Gut Are Talking to Your Brain. Scientists Want to Know What They’re Saying.
results.abstract: The body’s microbial community may influence the brain and behavior, perhaps even playing a role in dementia, autism and other disorders.

results.title: When Is the Surgeon Too Old to Operate?
results.abstract: A handful of hospitals have instituted mandatory screening procedures for medical professionals over 70. Many have been unenthusiastic about the idea.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Herbert Dardik at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center in New Jersey. "The clock ticks," he said, "and I’ve become an advocate for evaluation.”

results.title: 9 Tons of Pangolin Scales Are Seized in Hong Kong
results.abstract: Officials believe the scales came from nearly 14,000 pangolins. All eight pangolin species are endangered, some critically.

multimedia.caption: Sacks of seized pangolin scales were displayed by Hong Kong customs officials on Friday, along with elephant tusks they said were found in the same shipment.
Sacks of seized pangolin scales were displayed by Hong Kong customs officials on Friday, along with elephant tusks they said were found in the same shipment.

results.title: Gigantic Cavity in Antarctica Glacier Is a Product of Rapid Melting, Study Finds
results.abstract: Scientists discovered an underwater cavity with an area about two-thirds of Manhattan in the Thwaites Glacier. They say it’s a direct impact of climate change.

multimedia.caption: The Thwaites Glacier in western Antarctica is already responsible for about 4 percent of the world’s rising sea levels, according to NASA.
The Thwaites Glacier in western Antarctica is already responsible for about 4 percent of the world’s rising sea levels, according to NASA.

results.title: Sackler Scion’s Email Reveals Push for High-Dose OxyContin, New Lawsuit Disclosures Claim
results.abstract: Purdue Pharma tried to maximize profits by marketing the drug to keep patients on higher doses for longer periods, a lawsuit charges.

multimedia.caption: Demonstrators outside Purdue Pharma’s headquarters in Stamford, Conn., in August.

results.title: It’s Still Cold. Our Midwest Readers Tell Us How to Make the Most of the Polar Vortex.
results.abstract: Our readers found novel ways to entertain themselves in weather so cold, even the mail was not delivered.

results.title: He Swallowed a Toothpick. It Could Have Killed Him.
results.abstract: For several weeks, a young athlete’s symptoms stumped doctors, despite tests and scans. Unnoticed in a sandwich or wrap, toothpicks can do a surprising amount of damage in the digestive tract, and beyond.

multimedia.caption: Though not common, 136 injuries similar to this toothpick case study  have been reported in medical journals, and nearly 10 percent were fatal.
Though not common, 136 injuries similar to this toothpick case study  have been reported in medical journals, and nearly 10 percent were fatal.

results.title: E-Cigarettes Are Effective at Helping Smokers Quit, a Study Says
results.abstract: A yearlong, randomized trial in England showed that e-cigarettes were almost twice as successful as products like patches or gum for smoking cessation.

multimedia.caption: A study of English smokers found that e-cigarettes are nearly twice as effective as conventional nicotine replacement products like patches or gum, for quitting.

results.abstract: Three separate recalls have been issued this month by Tyson Foods and Perdue. What’s happening to America’s chicken nuggets?

results.title: Opioid Lawsuits Are Headed to Trial. Here's Why the Stakes Are Getting Uglier.
results.abstract: The judge presiding over all the federal cases had hoped to settle them by now. But the behemoth litigation is only becoming more bloated, contentious and difficult to resolve.

multimedia.caption: Judge Dan Aaron Polster will preside over three consolidated lawsuits as a bellwether, or test case, in one of the most complicated legal battles in U.S. history.

results.title: U.S. Midwest Freezes, Australia Burns: This Is the Age of Weather Extremes
results.abstract: Numbing cold hit parts of the United States as wildfires raged in Australia’s record-breaking heat. Here's the climate change connection.

results.title: How to Avoid Frostbite and Hypothermia in Extreme Cold Weather
results.abstract: During extreme cold, the blood rushes to the center of the body to protect vital organs, and the body temperature can fall to dangerous lows. The best advice is to stay inside, experts say.

multimedia.caption: Morning commuters on Adams Street in Chicago on Tuesday. Forecasters warned that the frigid weather will worsen, and could be life-threatening.

results.abstract: China in 2010 promised to curb methane emissions. In the first five years, it failed to keep its promise, according to new research based on satellite data.

results.title: Joshua Trees Destroyed in National Park During Shutdown May Take Centuries to Regrow
results.abstract: A small number of thousands of signature trees in Joshua Tree National Park were destroyed during the shutdown. Conservationists said replacing them will take time.

multimedia.caption: With most of the park’s rangers furloughed, vandals and inconsiderate guests ran amok. A small number of the park’s namesake trees were outright destroyed. Replacing them may take centuries, according to conservationists.

results.title: Why It Hurts to Lose Sleep
results.abstract: Sleep deprivation can make your physical aches more painful. A new study begins to explain how that happens.

multimedia.caption: A subject in a sleep-disorder clinic in France. Recent research found that staying awake all night can increase a person's sensitivity to pain the next morning by as much as 30 percent.

results.title: Study Offers Hint of Hope for Staving Off Dementia in Some People
results.abstract: People who received intensive treatment for hypertension were less likely to develop minor cognitive problems than those receiving standard treatment.

results.title: Don’t Kiss Your Pet Hedgehogs, C.D.C. Warns
results.abstract: Eleven people across eight states have been infected with a strain of salmonella linked to pet hedgehogs, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Eleven people have been infected with a strain of salmonella linked to pet hedgehogs, the C.D.C. reported. Their advice: Don’t kiss or snuggle your hedgehogs, and wash your hands after caring for them.

results.title: These Patients Had Sickle-Cell Disease. Experimental Therapies Might Have Cured Them.
results.abstract: Success against sickle-cell would be “the first genetic cure of a common genetic disease” and could free tens of thousands of Americans from agonizing pain.

multimedia.caption: Brandon Williams received gene therapy to replace sickle cells with healthy hemoglobin. His sister, Britney, died of complications of sickle-cell disease. He has a tattoo of her name on his right arm.

results.title: When the Cat Needs a Painkiller
results.abstract: Owners have few good options for cats that need long-term relief.

results.title: Alaska Hunter Who Killed Cubs in Bear Den Gets 3 Months in Jail
results.abstract: A father-and-son hunting pair fatally shot a mother black bear and her newborn cubs in April. A camera used for wildlife research captured the whole thing.

multimedia.caption: A female bear, part of the Prince William Sound black bear study in Alaska, emerged from her den with a cub in April 2018. Another female bear in the study was killed, along with her cubs, by a father-and-son hunting pair.
multimedia.copyright: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service/A.D.F.G. Prince William Sound Black Bear Study.

results.title: ‘This Could Be the End’ for NASA’s Mars Opportunity Rover
results.abstract: The agency has received only silence from the intrepid explorer since contact was lost during a global dust storm on the red planet last June.

multimedia.caption: An artist's rendering of NASA's Opportunity rover on the surface of Mars.

results.title: A Sharper Picture of Ultima Thule From NASA’s New Horizons
results.abstract: The spacecraft captured the image when it was 4,200 miles from the object in the solar system’s distant Kuiper belt.

multimedia.caption: The Kuiper belt object Ultima Thule, about 1 billion miles beyond Pluto, encountered by the New Horizons spacecraft on Jan. 1, 2019.
multimedia.copyright: NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, via Southwest Research Institute, via Associated Press
